text: we hope they will the Syrian opposition
was gathered together in Riyadh in an
unprecedented move they all of the
factions represented they agreed on a
platform on a vision for Syria they
agreed on what the new Syria should look
like and the process for getting there
and they picked their negotiating team
and so now they're ready it is the
regime of Bashar al-assad that has been
dragging its feet and says announcement
well we will see it has said many things
before that it didn't comply with we
hope that the talks will begin on the
25th so we can launch the process that
will lead to the establishment of an
interim governing council that will
assume power from the Bashar regime and
that will then move towards writing a
new constitution and having elections
and we hope that and expect that during
the interim period of the transition
period Bashar Assad will exit because he
has absolutely no role to play in the
future Syria if the talks go ahead on
the 25th you will have to sit at the
same table as Iran are you going to be
able to work together now that you don't
have diplomatic relations and the
strains are at an unprecedented low well
I think that the the talks will be
between Syrians and Syrians we will not
be at the table normally around but we
will we we are committed to the process
the transition process in Syria we are
committed to the what is called now the
Vienna process the Geneva principles and
the principles enshrined in the UN
Security Council resolutions in spite of
our differences with Iran you've had
talks with the u.s. second to say John
Kerry he's possibly leaving London to go
to an announcement that sanctions will
be lifted against Iran did you have
concerns that you expressed to him we
have concerns about Iran's behavior in
general Iran is a country that has to
decide whether it is a revolution or a
nation-state if it is a revolution it is
irrational and emotional and impulsive
and expansionary and irrational
difficult to deal with if it is a nation
state nation-states tend to be
reasonable rational actors and they know
their limits and they work on the basis
of what is mutually beneficial and so
the with Iran we not sure we don't know
if it's a revolution or a nation-state
we
that will see itself as a nation-state
and act as such but what we have seen
unfortunately in the last 35 years is a
country that has used murder a country
that has used terrorism a country that
has used sectarianism a country that has
interfered in the affairs of others in
the region in a very destructive and
destabilizing manner that is what
concerns us but they have legal equally
so they have concerns about you and your
behavior in the region your decision to
suddenly cut off ties the execution of
Nimr al-nimr what business does Iran
have in it
Iran puts to death more than 1,000
people a year that's their business we
don't know why they were put to death in
our cases was transparent Iran is
arguing that this man was a man of
religion at peaceful protester he was a
terrorist he was as much a man of
religion as Osama bin Laden was he was
recruiting he was inciting he was
equipping he was plotting and he was
executing terrorist attacks that led to
the death of a number of security
officials in Saudi Arabia and that's why
he was sentenced to death and so with
all due respect to Iran they have no
business interfering in our judiciary 1
& 2 the last thing they can say is that
Saudi a be engaged in any kind of
aggression towards them we have been on
the receiving end of Iran's aggression
for decades now
